                                                  Play                           Mastering English: International Summer in New York City is a series of dynamic, three-week summer programs of study that are offered by the NYU School of Professional Studies American Language Institute (ALI). It provides a wide range of language courses and cultural learning experiences, which are designed to meet the academic needs of international high school and college students, as well as adult learners. Four programs pair high-quality, English language instruction with a focus on various content areas including: global business; the American college experience; and the history, art, and culture of NYC. Integrated skills classrooms blend content and structure, allowing you to apply what you have learned immediately in your new surroundings. The program’s location, in the heart of New York City, provides incomparable access to the cultures of the world. We extend our classroom to the streets, offering you the opportunity to immerse yourself in the language and the culture—the basis for being able to express yourself with ease and with accuracy.   Don't miss this once-in-a-lifetime opportunity.            Program Cost        The program cost includes ​tuition, on-campus housing, 10 meals per week with $30 dining dollars, and excursions. For high school students enrolled in American College Experience and New York City Experience , trips to Boston and Washington, D.C. are included in the cost. For commuter students, the cost will be slightly different. Please contact alimasteringenglishnyc@nyu.edu for additional pricing information. We are known for our broad view of the discipline, and understand "literature" to mean writing in all media, and its study to include all the ways in which texts have been produced, re-produced, circulated, and read, along with the modes of classification and the definitions of enjoyment used to understand them. The scholarly methods we employ, and in which we train our students, include close reading, historical and archival research, literary theory, the history of the book, media theory, and cultural analysis.
